group-type.name: Verbs that have subjects that are text-bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
Verbs that have objects that are text-bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
Verbs that have objects that are claims.
Verbs that may not take objects
Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 70% or greater.
group-type.desc: If subject and object are in the same language, the quantity is measured by agreement after normalization, ignoring accentuation, capitalization, punctuation, and word spaces. If they are in different languages, the quantity is measured by the number of words in one source that correspond to words in the other.

group-type.name: Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 40% to 70%.
Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 5% to 40%.
Verbs that indicate comparisons between subject and object.
Verbs that establish symmetrical relationships between subject and object. If X [verb] Y then Y [verb] X.
Verbs that establish transitive relationships between subject and object. If X [verb] Y and Y [verb] Z then X [verb] Z.
Verbs that require or or more <locus>.
group-type.desc: These verbs are intended to support claims about how specific persons or scripta corroborate or depart from the reading of a particular locus of text.

algorithm.name: Stylesheet to populate a TAN-A-div file from collections.

item.name: is about
discusses
item.desc: The textual subject is about the object, normally a topic.

item.name: paraphrases
item.desc: The textual subject paraphrases the textual object. Relationship may be direct or indirect.

item.name: quotes
item.desc: The textual subject quotes from the textual object. Relationship may be direct or indirect. This implies that the subject postdates the object.

item.name: alludes or refers to
refers or alludes to
item.desc: The textual subject alludes to or refers to the textual object. The allusion or reference may be direct or indirect. This implies that the subject postdates the object.

Although some people may distinguish alluding from refering, this vocabulary item does not, since the distinction is very frequently hard to identify, and many people use the terms interchangeably. If gradation is needed, @cert should be used.

item.name: parallels
item.desc: The textual subject is topically or textually parallel to the textual object. Any textual relationship that exists may go from roughly similar up through verbatim. Nothing is implied about whether subject quotes from object, vice versa, or both draw from a common source. Nothing is implied about the chronological priority of the object or subject.

item.name: comments on
is commentary in (work)
item.desc: Relates a work to a work that contains a set of explanatory or critical notes on a described work. See http://rdaregistry.info/Elements/w.xml

item.name: omits
item.desc: The subject omits the reading at the locus. The claim takes no object.

item.name: agrees
item.desc: The subject agrees with the reading at the locus. The claim takes no object.

item.name: prepends
praeposuit
item.desc: The subject adds words defined by the object to the beginning of the locus.

item.name: appends
postposuit
item.desc: The subject adds words defined by the object to the end of the locus.

item.name: replaces
has other reading
item.desc: The subject replaces the reading at the locus with the words defined by the object.

item.name: moves to a new physical division
resumes at
item.desc: The beginning of the locus coincides with the beginning of a new physical division in the subject. This verb is comparable to <tei:milestone>

item.name: indicates
provides written evidence that
item.desc: The subject provides evidence for a certain claim.
